p.s: In William Shakespeare's Sonnet 65, published 1609 in his book Shakespeare's sonnets the speaker talks about the love as well as the beauty that comes along with it and how it is slowly fading away over time.
William Shakespeare's poem is a sonnet with fourteen lines, typically for a Shakespearean sonnet it is divided in three quatrains and one couplet in the end.
The rhyme scheme in the quatrains is a cross rhyme ABAB CDCD EFEF and the last two lines are a rhyming couplet GG.
William Shakespeare uses an iambic parameter throughout the poem.
In the first quatrain, line one to four, the author mentions the power that the mortality holds against every force, wetherwhether it be nature or beauty.
The second quatrain from lines five to eight, talked about time that can and will destroy wha comes in its way.
The last and third quatrain, from line nine to twelve, the speaker is questioning for something or someone that is able as well as willing to stop timestime's curse.

The couplet, from lines thirteen to fourteen, explains that it is impossible to unpower the time, but that the love he has and feels will be remembered in black ink, which means it will be remembered in poems.
The sonnet reveals word themes, for example the theme of nature.
The words used are brass, stone, earth, sea and flower (l. 1-4).
Another word theme are words, that have beautiful meanings like bright, beauty, miracle, or summer (l. 3, 5, 13, 14).
